results.title: The Lost Thing: character
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘The Lost Thing’ production team discusses the challenges they faced creating the friendly and unthreatening character of the lost thing and the techniques used to convey emotion in a character that does not speak and has no facial features.

results.title: Asking Around
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.brief_description: Shaun Tan (author and co-director)describes some of his original concepts for the book of ‘The Lost Thing’ and how these were translated and changed for the film adaptation. Other interviewees Tom Bryant (3D artist)and Leo Baker (animator)discuss points of similarity and difference between the book and film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.description: Shaun Tan (author and co-director)describes some of his original concepts for the book of ‘The Lost Thing’ and how these were translated and changed for the film adaptation. Other interviewees Tom Bryant (3D artist)and Leo Baker (animator)discuss points of similarity and difference between the book and film.

results.title: Morning paper
results.creator_credit: Donald Carter, Darrel Catling, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The story of a newspaper during wartime. Shows how the news is gathered and prepared for the press in spite of the threat of bombs. Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Donald Carter, Darrel Catling, H. Bruce Woolfe and Gaumont-British Instructional

Describes the composition and checking of the pages, the creation of curved steroes to fit the rotary presses and various other tasks that must be completed before the paper can be put to bed.

results.title: Hollywood Costume: Interview with Jan Chapman and Janet Patterson
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery, Mike Kenneally and ACMI
results.brief_description:
The 2009 film ‘Bright Star’ (directed by Jane Campion) tells the story of the romance between the English poet John Keats (1795 - 1821) and Fanny Brawne.
In this interview, ‘Bright Star’ producer Jan Chapman and costume designer Janet Patterson discuss the creative process behind costume design, and the design choices that went into making one of the costumes for the character Fanny Brawne (played in the film by Abbie Cornish).
The character’s crimson gown costume was on display during the ACMI Melbourne Winter Masterpieces ‘Hollywood Costume’ exhibition (2013).
Clips from ‘Bright Star’ (2009) courtesy of Hopscotch Films.

results.title: The Anzac Story
results.creator_credit: George I. Malcolm, Frank Hunter and ABC
results.brief_description: This video contains two programs pertaining to the history of the Anzacs using archival footage, drawings and stills and narrated by Barry Lineham. “Prelude to glory” - Presents a brief historical overview of Captain Cook’s landings in New Zealand and Australia and the following events which took place including colonisation, the chain of British governors, a Treaty with the Maoris, Federation in Australia, and the eventual lead up to World War I. With the advent of the War came the formation of the Anzac Corps, an alliance between the Australian and New Zealand defence forces, and a commitment by the Anzacs to fight for the British Empire in a war half a world away. Shows the sailing of the first convoy, the naval battle and sinking of the German battle ship “Emden” and the arrival of the Anzacs in Egypt. “Gallipoli” - Tells the story of this ill-fated war against the Turks, the tragic mistakes, the chaos and disorganisation, and the horrendous loss of young Anzacs (10,000 soldiers) from the botched up landing on 25 April 1915 in a small bay south of Ari Burnu (renamed Anzac Cove) to the eventual evacuation of all troops in December 1915.

results.title: Take me to your Lager
